titleInfo.title: Map of southern Germany and northern Switzerland

subject.topic: United States. Army. Air Service. Aero Squadron, 95th
World War, 1914-1918 -- Prisoners and prisons, American

mods.abstract: Map of southern Germany and northern Switzerland showing the route George W. Puryear took on his escape from the POW camp at Villingen, Germany. Villingen is circled on the map. The places where he stopped to sleep are also circled, and the date in October 1918 when he stopped there is written next to each circle. There are two X's across the Rhine from Waldshut, marking where he came out of the river and the house where he was first given aid.
mods.accessCondition: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees that may be necessary for the intended use.

relatedItem.abstract: This collection documents the careers in the United States Army Air Service during and after World War I of two brothers from Gallatin, Tennessee. George Wright Puryear was a fighter pilot with the 95th Aero Squadron, was taken prisoner by the Germans, and subsequently became the first American officer to escape from a German prisoner of war camp. Alfred Isaac Puryear spent the war stationed in Paris, France, as a supply officer with the Army Air Service, and became an airship (dirigible) pilot after the war. This collection provides a fascinating visual record of the early history and aircraft of the Army Air Service, which would become the United States Air Force after World War II.

subject.topic: United States. Army. Air Service. Aero Squadron, 95th
World War, 1914-1918 -- Prisoners and prisons, American

mods.abstract: Studio portrait of Lieutenant George W. Puryear wearing his uniform and garrison (or "overseas") cap. His uniform displays his pilot's wings and two overseas chevrons on his left sleeve (each chevron denoting six months of service in a theater of operation).

titleInfo.title: American Prisoners of War at Burg Trausnitz, Landshut, Germany

subject.topic: World War, 1914-1918 -- Prisoners and prisons, American

mods.abstract: Top row: Harold H. McChesney, Horace Wells, Alexander Roberts, William Tyler, James N. Hall, Henry C. Lewis, G. S. Harvey. Middle row: "Bugs" Raymond, ? Connolly, ? Hollingsworth, Alfred B. Baker, ? Whiton. Bottom row: ? White, Zenos R. Miller, Robert G. Browning, Van Winkle Todd, ? Gorman, William Kidder, ? MacElvain.

subject.topic: World War, 1914-1918 -- Prisoners and prisons, American -- Personal narratives

mods.abstract: "The Airman's Escape" is George W. Puryear's autobiographical account of his capture and escape from a German POW camp during World War I. His account appeared in the April 1919 (p. 452-462) and May 1919 (p. 615-628) issues of Atlantic Monthly magazine. The pages were removed from the magazine and bound together into a booklet. The story is also reprinted (verbatim) as Appendix B in Harold Buckley's book "Squadron 95" (New York: Arno Press, 1972).
